title: 108_hr2711
content: The "Student Loan Fairness Act of 2003" allows for the removal of the prohibition on refinancing consolidation loans and gives student loan borrowers the choice of loan consolidator. The "Student Loan Fairness Act of 2003" allows borrowers to choose their loan consolidator and mandates lenders to provide clear information about consolidation loans. The "Student Loan Fairness Act of 2003" mandates lenders to provide clear information about consolidation loans, including the effects on interest rates, repayment plans, pre-payment options, and differences between variable and fixed rates. The "Student Loan Fairness Act of 2003" requires lenders to provide borrowers with clear and conspicuous notices about the effects of using a consolidation loan to discharge student loans, including information on fixed and variable interest rates, available repayment plans, and the impact on monthly and total payments. The "Student Loan Fairness Act of 2003" mandates lenders to disclose details such as interest rates, monthly payments, total interest, repayment term length, and prepayment options to student borrowers. SEC. 4. INTEREST RATES ON CONSOLIDATED AND RECONSOLIDATED LOANS. Interest Rate Changes in the Higher Education Act of 1965 amended to adjust rates for new loans between October 1, 1998, and January 1, 2004. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amended interest rates for new loans between October 1, 1998, and January 1, 2004. The applicable rate of interest for loans during specific periods was set at 2.3 percent, not exceeding 8.25 percent. The interest rates for different types of loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965 were amended between October 1, 1998, and January 1, 2004. The rates were adjusted to 1.7 percent for certain loans, 3.1 percent for PLUS loans, and 9.0 percent for consolidation loans during this period. The interest rates for loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965 were amended between October 1, 1998, and January 1, 2004. The applicable rate of interest on the unpaid principal balance of consolidated loans was determined by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury. The rate was either the weighted average of the interest rates on the loans consolidated or 8.25 percent. For loans made after January 1, 2004, the interest rate is determined based on the bond equivalent rate of 91-day Treasury bills auctioned on June 1 plus 2.3 percent, not exceeding 6.8 percent. This applies to loans under section 428B as well. The applicable rate of interest for consolidation loans under section 428C, received by an eligible lender on or after January 1, 2004, is determined based on the bond equivalent rate of 91-day Treasury bills auctioned on the final auction held prior to June 1 plus 2.3 percent, not exceeding 6.8 percent. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow eligible lenders to charge a borrower an origination fee of up to 0.5 percent for consolidation loans made under section 428C on or after January 1, 2004. The interest rate for these loans is determined based on the bond equivalent rate of 91-day Treasury bills plus 2.3 percent, capped at 6.8 percent. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows lenders to charge a 0.5 percent origination fee for consolidation loans made after January 1, 2004. Amendments also change dates in various sections to reflect this update.
